content.description: This route starts out just right of the right-hand bottom trees and has a covering of crispy lichen (hence the name), so you need cleaning gear to make the most of this. Once you get above the trees a bit, the growth almost disappears. I love the route because its a nice steady challenge the whole way up and offers a few different options to send after the halfway point. You could make this a 5.10c if you want by simply choosing a slightly different line.
content.protection: No fixed gear as of this post, and very little pro. Your best to TR.
content.location: All the way to the right side of the base area around the back of the clump of trees.

content.description: Snake Hole starts with an easy set of hand and foot holds with one 'leap of faith' in the beginning, then settles into a nice line of classic 5.7 stuff. A great way to start the day and warm up.
content.protection: Pro can be a little spaced out, and requires following 'You Crack Me Up' after the bottom 3rd. Mostly medium cams and larger nuts will work. This is a wilderness area, so there is no fixed gear of any kind.
content.location: The start of this route is just behind the small tree just to the right of the largest tree on the bottom. Refer to posted picture for the area.

content.description: This is a great and entertaining route with several lines to challenge you through the middle section, some 5.7 and some 5.9. Whats nice is it starts out as a 5.5 or 5.6 warm up, and continues to get tougher the higher you go.
content.protection: No fixed gear and very scarce pro.
content.location: This is the right central route indicated on the area pic. It starts in an easy inside corner behind the bottom right-hand trees.

content.description: The crux for this route is in the very beginning, about 10 feet up. Have not figured a path through the bulge yet, but a though line around the right side will get you to the nice classic flake and finger stuff.
content.location: Left center of the main climbing area starting under the obvious bulge. See area photo for the visual Beta.

content.description:
Keep in mind that you are in a Wilderness area, The nearest hospital is in Grand Marais, it will take at-least 2 hours to get there and you'll not have cell phone service. Leave No Trace principles should also be followed. So cleaning off lichen and chalk are not permitted. For waste Pack it in Pack it out both human and trash. None of the routes are hard enough to warrant chalk on top rope so lets help the Forest Service preserve this wonderful place for generations to come.

 This cliff face is granite and mostly hard rock with a few soft spots. Being in the wilderness area of the Minnesota Boundary Waters it is actually quite busy with groups passing through to see the views from the top of the cliff, often with clusters often exceeding the boundary waters limit of 9 people and 4 canoes especially during peak season. The climbs here are fun though and mostly TR (Read: bring lots of anchor line), with a few lines offering up somewhat limited and fiddly pro. Not much protection from the sun for most of the day (please don't pee on the trees that do offer some), but usually a nice breeze and good swimming.
